metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: Statements as to the Trapier Family  Paul Trapier emigrated from Grenoble in Dauphiny France in 1695 and married Elizabeth, daughter of Jaques de Gue, who had preceded him in emigrating, about 1690.  This Elizabeth de Gue, not being permitted to leave France, was concealed in a Hogshead marked “Poterie” and thus conveyed on board the vessel in which she reached America.  This Paul Trapier settled in what was called French Santee, in the Parish of St. Stephens, on a Plantation, he called La Grande Fontaine.  His son Paul Trapier, afterwards moved to Georgetown, where acquired large Estates and in 1743, married Magdalene Horry, daughter of Elias Horry, after her death Mrs. Waties; he died Oct. 24 1793.  His son Paul Trapier was born in 1749 and was sent to England to be educated at Eton and afterwards to St John’s College, Cambridge.  Upon his return he became a member of the Constitutional Assembly of South Carolina, (Authority, Moultries American Revolution in Carolina and Georgia, Page 15), also a member of the Committee of Safety for Georgetown, S.C., (same authority, Pages 43 & 50.  He married his first cousin, Elizabeth Foisin and died at the early age of 29, leaving three sons and one daughter, Paul, Ben and Wyndam, Magdalen Elizabeth who married John Keith.  Paul Trapier married Sarah Alicia Shubrick, daughter of Col. Thomas Shubrick in the year 1802.  He, Paul Trapier was born in 1772 and was sent in 1776 to Cambridge, New England, where he graduated at the early age of 18.  They had three sons and three daughters: [who?] [died?] [young?] Paul, who married, Sarah Russell Dehon, Thomas Shubrick, who died young, Richard Shubrick who married his first cousin Whydam Trapier, Harriet Cordelia, who died young; Mary Elizabeth, who died single; Alicia Pauline, who married Issac W. Hayne.
